title: What components are needed to build a smartphone? - Quora

response.answer_text: the most basic ones? the list is fairly long. but I’ll try to sum it up: Chipset (AKA a platform.)this is the most crucial piece in a smartphone. this lets you use the phone basically.POSSIBLE VENDORS:Qualcomm:Wireless Technology & Innovation | Mobile Technology | Qualcomm Samsung- Exynos:Exynos Mobile Processor for Faster Speed | SamsungMediatek:MediaTek - Semiconductor Technology and Cutting-Edge SoCBroadcom:Broadcom Inc. | Connecting EverythingKirin:KirinEach chipset has their own pros and cons. select carefully before purchasing it and according to your needsCamera (s). to enable shooting beautiful pictures and selfies. as well as record awesome videos.Peripherals (Charge port, Audio port)Microphone module (For doing a phone call)Speaker, Earpiece moduleSENSORS! (the crucial ones are Proximity, accelerometer, Gyro, and Compass)Battery to power this up. type Li-ion or Li PolymerDisplay with digitizerChassis in the correct size.Software, you can use Android only. as iOS is not an open source OS.Other goodies you’d like to have in your phone. like a fingerprint sensor, Face scanner. FaceID module. and many more!cards slot for SIMs and MicroSD (MicroSD is optional)antennas for everything.NFC module. (not exactly a must. but it’s a good touch)Setup: ENOUGH money and patience to order the parts neededCoding Knowledgeteam that will aid you in building ita LOT of researchexperts that will help youA CRAZY sh*tload of guides.Please rememebr it has to pass TENAA, 3C, Bluetooth certification and WiFi Certification BEFORE you can call your device a phone. without these regulatories your device is not recognised as a phone.

A smartphone is very complex and requires alot of parts in order to make it work. But the basic parts of building a smartphone would be The DisplayThe CameraThe SOC or System on ChipModemsSensorsBatterySpeakersMemoryOf course all this would be useless without the Operating System (Software) as that's a very important part of the equation. But this should give you a good picture of what's needed without getting too technical.
